unnormalised: Property prices in Mumbai's posh areas have shot up like crazy! You won't believe it, but a 2BHK flat in Bandra is now easily costing around Rs. 5 crores. Brokers are saying it’s all due to the increased demand and limited supply. Land rates in areas like Juhu and Pali Hill have crossed ₹80,000 per sq ft.
normalised: Property prices in Mumbai's posh areas have shot up like crazy! You won't believe it, but a two B H K flat in Bandra is now easily costing around rupee five crore. Brokers are saying it’s all due to the increased demand and limited supply. Land rates in areas like Juhu and Pali Hill have crossed rupee eighty thousand per square foot.

unnormalised: Even the slightly less fancy areas are seeing a huge jump. A 1BHK in Andheri, which used to be around Rs. 80 lakhs, is now selling for upwards of ₹1.2 crores. My cousin, Priya Sharma, was telling me how tough it is to find something decent even with a budget of Rs. 90 lakhs.
normalised: Even the slightly less fancy areas are seeing a huge jump. A one B H K in Andheri, which used to be around rupee eighty lakh, is now selling for upwards of rupee one point two crore. My cousin, Priya Sharma, was telling me how tough it is to find something decent even with a budget of rupee ninety lakh.

unnormalised: Developers are launching these super-premium projects, you know, the ones with all the fancy amenities. One project near BKC is quoting prices as high as Rs. 10 crore for a 3BHK! It’s like, who even has that kind of money?! The average carpet area is supposedly around 1500 sq ft for that price.
normalised: Developers are launching these super-premium projects, you know, the ones with all the fancy amenities. One project near B K C is quoting prices as high as rupee ten crore for a three B H K! It’s like, who even has that kind of money?! The average carpet area is supposedly around one thousand five hundred square feet for that price.

unnormalised: Experts are predicting a further rise of 10-15% in the next 6 months. They say the low interest rates (around 7.5% on home loans) are also fueling the demand. Plus, with more and more people migrating to Mumbai for jobs, the pressure on housing is only going to increase.
normalised: Experts are predicting a further rise of ten to fifteen percent in the next six months. They say the low interest rates (around seven point five percent on home loans) are also fueling the demand. Plus, with more and more people migrating to Mumbai for jobs, the pressure on housing is only going to increase.

unnormalised: So, if you're thinking of buying property in Mumbai, better prepone your plans! Otherwise, you might just miss the bus (or should I say, the local train?) and end up paying even more. Looks like renting is the only option for many of us middle-class folks these days.
normalised: So, if you're thinking of buying property in Mumbai, better prepone your plans! Otherwise, you might just miss the bus (or should I say, the local train?) and end up paying even more. Looks like renting is the only option for many of us middle-class folks these days.
